docs.title: mcup
docs.text:
mcup is a command-line tool for quickly creating Minecraft servers. Inspired by tools like rustup and npm init, mcup simplifies the setup process and allows for templated server creation with support for multiple server types (e.g., vanilla, Spigot). Made for both advanced server managers and beginners setting up their first server.

Getting Started Commands Overview

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Fast server setup with a single command
  • Template system for custom and reusable server setups
  • Locker system for managing supported server versions and download links
  • Designed for Linux (Also supports Windows and macOS)

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to mcup! We appreciate your help in making this project better. This guide will help you get started with setting up your development environment, making changes, and submitting a pull request.

docs.title: Fork the Repository
docs.text: First, create a fork of the mcup repository on GitHub. This gives you your own copy of the project to work on.

docs.title: Clone Your Fork
docs.text:
Clone your forked repository to your local machine:

git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/mcup.git
cd mcup

docs.title: Set Up Development Environment
docs.text:
It is recommended to use a virtual environment to manage dependencies:

Linux / macOSWindows 
# Create a virtual environment
python3 -m venv .venv

# Activate the virtual environment
source .venv/bin/activate

# Create a virtual environment
python -m venv .venv

# Activate the virtual environment
.venv/Scripts/activate

Install the project dependencies and the project itself in editable mode:

pip install -e .

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
Here is a quick overview of the project's structure to help you navigate the codebase:

  • .github/: GitHub-related configuration files (workflows, issue templates).
  • debian/: Files for building the .deb package.
  • mcup/: The main source code directory.
    • mcup.core: Core application logic (handlers, utils, status codes).
    • mcup.cli: Command-line interface code (commands, UI components).
    • mcup.devtools: Development tools to assist with testing and maintenance.
  • rpm/: Files for building the .rpm package.
  • docs/: Documentation files (MkDocs).

docs.title: Running Locally
docs.text: You can run the CLI directly from the source code to test your changes.

docs.title: Using Entry Point (Recommended)
docs.text:
The easiest way to run the CLI is by using the installed mcup command within your virtual environment. Since you installed the package in editable mode (pip install -e .), any changes you make to the code are immediately reflected.

  1. Ensure your virtual environment is activated.
  2. Run the command:
mcup [command]

docs.title: Using Helper Scripts
docs.text:
We provide helper scripts that handle the execution for you, which can be useful if you haven't activated your virtual environment manually.

Linux / macOSWindows 
./mcup.sh [command]

mcup.bat [command]

docs.title: Using Python Module
docs.text:
Alternatively, you can run the package directly using Python:

python3 -m mcup [command]

docs.title: Building the Project
docs.text:
To build the distributable packages (DEB, RPM), use the provided build script.

./build.sh

This will generate the packages in the dist directory.

Note

You can skip specific package builds using flags:

  • --skip-deb: Skip building the Debian package.
  • --skip-rpm: Skip building the RPM package.

docs.title: Commit Message Convention
docs.text:
We follow the Conventional Commits style to keep our commit history clear and easy to understand.

Each commit message should start with a type prefix, followed by a colon and a short description:

<type>: <short description>

docs.title: Common Types
docs.text: Type Description Example feat A new feature feat: add support for YAML config loading fix A bug fix fix: prevent crash when config file is missing docs Documentation only changes docs: update usage section in README.md style Code style changes (formatting, etc) style: reformat code with Black refactor Refactoring code without changing behavior refactor: extract validation logic test Adding or updating tests test: add unit tests for CLI argument parser build Changes to build scripts or dependencies build: upgrade rich library chore Other changes chore: update license year

docs.title: Optional Scope
docs.text:
You can optionally specify a scope in parentheses to indicate which part of the codebase is affected:

fix(config): handle missing default values

docs.title: How to Write a Good Commit Message
docs.text:
• Keep the message concise (under 72 characters).
  • Use the imperative mood ("fix bug" not "fixed bug").
  • Explain what and why briefly.

docs.title: Submitting a Pull Request
docs.text:
1. Create a new branch for your feature or fix: git checkout -b feat/my-new-feature.
  2. Make your changes and test them locally.
  3. Commit your changes following the Commit Message Convention.
  4. Push your branch to your fork: git push origin feat/my-new-feature.
  5. Open a Pull Request on the main repository.
  6. Provide a clear description of your changes and why they are necessary.

We will review your PR and provide feedback. Thank you for contributing!

docs.title: Commands Overview
docs.text: mcup provides a variety of commands to manage Minecraft servers, templates, configuration, and more.

docs.title: Available Commands
docs.text:
Command Description server Create and list Minecraft servers. template Manage server templates. config Manage user configuration settings. update Update the internal locker file with the latest server definitions. about detailed information about the installed mcup version.

Use mcup <command> --help to see detailed help for a specific command.

docs.title: About
docs.text: The about command displays detailed information about the installed version of mcup, including the version number, author, and copyright information.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: mcup about

docs.title: Server Management
docs.text: The server command group allows you to create new Minecraft servers and list available server types and versions.

docs.title: Create a Server
docs.text:
Create a new Minecraft server with the specified type and version.

mcup server create <server_type> <server_version> [path] [flags]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description server_type The type of server to create (e.g., paper, fabric). server_version The version of the server to install (e.g., 1.17, 1.20.1). path (Optional) The directory where the server will be created. Defaults to the current directory (.).

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Description --no-configs Skip the generation of configuration files (e.g. server.properties). --no-defaults Prompt for all configuration values, ignoring any defaults. --all-defaults Use default values for all configuration options without prompting. --skip-java-check Skip the check for Java installation and version compatibility.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Create a Paper 1.20.1 server in the current directory:

mcup server create paper 1.20.1

Create a Paper 1.20.1 server in a specific directory:

mcup server create paper 1.20.1 ./my-server

Create a Paper 1.20.1 server using all default configuration values:

mcup server create paper 1.20.1 --all-defaults

docs.title: List Available Servers
docs.text:
List all available server types and their supported versions from the local locker.

mcup server list

This command will output a list of server types (like spigot, paper, fabric) and the versions available for each.

docs.title: Template Management
docs.text: The template command group allows you to manage server templates, which pre-configure server settings and files for quick deployment.

docs.title: Create a Template
docs.text:
Create a new template based on a specific server type and version. This will prompt you to configure the server settings which will be saved into the template.

mcup template create <server_type> <server_version> <template_name>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description server_type The type of server for the template (e.g., paper). server_version The version of the server (e.g., 1.20.1). template_name A unique name for your new template.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Create a template named survival-1.20 for a Paper 1.20.1 server:

mcup template create paper 1.20.1 survival-1.20

docs.title: Use a Template
docs.text:
Create a new server using an existing template.

mcup template use <template_name> [path]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description template_name The name of the template to use. path (Optional) The directory where the server will be created. Defaults to the current directory (.).

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Create a server from the survival-1.20 template in the current directory:

mcup template use survival-1.20

Create a server from the survival-1.20 template in a specific directory:

mcup template use survival-1.20 ./my-server

docs.title: List Templates
docs.text:
List all available templates.

mcup template list

docs.title: Import a Template
docs.text:
Import a template from a JSON file.

mcup template import <path>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description path Path to the template JSON file to import.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Import a template from backup.json:

mcup template import ./backup.json

docs.title: Export a Template
docs.text:
Export an existing template to a JSON file.

mcup template export <template_name> <destination>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description template_name The name of the template to export. destination The destination path or directory for the exported JSON file.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Export the survival-1.20 template to backup.json:

mcup template export survival-1.20 ./backup.json

docs.title: Delete a Template
docs.text:
Delete an existing template.

mcup template delete <template_name>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description template_name The name of the template to delete.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Delete the survival-1.20 template:

mcup template delete survival-1.20

docs.title: Refresh a Template
docs.text:
Update the download links and metadata within a template to match the current locker version.

mcup template refresh <template_name>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description template_name The name of the template to refresh.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Refresh the survival-1.20 template:

mcup template refresh survival-1.20

docs.title: Update Management
docs.text: The update command manually triggers an update of the internal locker file, which contains the definitions for available server types, versions, and download links.

docs.title: Update Locker
docs.text:
Update the local locker file to the latest version from the remote repository.

mcup update [flags]

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Description --force Force the update even if the local locker is already considered up-to-date.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Standard update check:

mcup update

Force an update:

mcup update --force

docs.title: User Configuration
docs.text: The config command group allows you to manage global user configuration settings for mcup. These settings persist across sessions.

docs.title: Known Configuration Keys
docs.text: Key Description Default Value java.path The path to the Java executable to use for running servers. java logging.level The logging level for the CLI output (e.g., DEBUG, INFO). INFO devtools.enabled Enable developer tools commands (confdiff, lockermgr). false advancedmode.enabled Enable advanced fields in the server configuration wizard. false locker.remote The URL of the remote locker file to use for updates. (Standard URL) locker.branch The branch of the remote locker repository to use (if applicable). main

docs.title: Get Configuration
docs.text:
Retrieve the value of a specific configuration key.

mcup config get <key>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description key The configuration key to retrieve.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Get the current Java path:

mcup config get java.path

docs.title: Set Configuration
docs.text:
Set the value for a specific configuration key.

mcup config set <key> <value>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description key The configuration key to set. value The value to assign to the key.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Set the Java path to a specific executable:

mcup config set java.path /usr/bin/java17

Enable developer tools:

mcup config set devtools.enabled true

docs.title: Remove Configuration
docs.text:
Remove a specific configuration key and its value. This will revert the key to its default value if one exists.

mcup config remove <key>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description key The configuration key to remove.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Remove the custom Java path setting:

mcup config remove java.path

docs.title: Clear Configuration
docs.text:
Clear all user configuration settings, resetting them to defaults.

mcup config clear

docs.title: List Configuration
docs.text:
List all current configuration keys and their values.

mcup config list

docs.title: Creating Your First Server
docs.text: This guide will walk you through the process of setting up your very first Minecraft server using mcup. We will create a Paper server, one of the most popular and performant server software options available.

docs.title: Check Availability
docs.text:
Before we begin, it's helpful to see what server options are available. You can view a list of all supported server types and versions by running:

mcup server list

This command outputs a list of server types (like vanilla, paper, neoforge) and their corresponding supported versions (e.g., 1.20.1, 1.19.4).

docs.title: Create the Server
docs.text:
Let's create the server. We'll specify the server type (paper) and the version (1.20.1). You can also specify a directory where you want the server to be created; if you don't, it will default to the current directory.

Run the following command:

mcup server create paper 1.20.1 ./my-survival-server

This tells mcup to:

  • Create a Paper server.
  • Use version 1.20.1.
  • Place all files in a new folder named my-survival-server.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Once the command runs, mcup will check if your installed Java version is compatible and then begin the interactive configuration wizard.

docs.title: EULA Acceptance
docs.text: You must accept the Minecraft EULA (End User License Agreement) to run a server. mcup automatically sets this to true in the configuration, but you are responsible for reading and complying with the agreement.

docs.title: Server Properties
docs.text: Next, you will configure basic server.properties settings. Press Enter or type Y to accept the default values (shown in the defaults preview) or type N to type your own. These core settings are presented for all server types.

docs.title: Advanced Configuration
docs.text:
Depending on the server type, mcup may prompt for additional configuration files. For example, Paper 1.20.1 servers require:

  • Bukkit Configuration (bukkit.yml)
  • Spigot Configuration (spigot.yml)
  • Paper Global Configuration (configs/paper-global.yml)
  • Paper World Defaults (configs/paper-world-defaults.yml)

Refer to the specific server documentation for details on these files.

docs.title: Start Script Configuration
docs.text:
Finally, you will configure the startup script. This script handles starting and auto-restarting your server. You may be asked for:

  • Screen name: The screen session name for the running server.
  • Heap Size (MB): Initial and maximum memory allocation for the JVM.
  • Aikar's Flags: Whether to use Aikar's optimization flags (highly recommended for performance).
  • Restart Settings: Maximum restart attempts and delay between restarts.

docs.title: Running the Server
docs.text:
After configuration, mcup downloads the necessary files and generates the configuration files and start script.

Navigate to your new server directory:

cd my-survival-server

Note

On Linux or macOS, ensure the start script is executable: 

chmod +x start.sh

To start your server, run the generated script for your operating system:

Linux / macOSWindows 
./start.sh

start.bat

Congratulations! Your server should now be starting up.

You can view its console by running screen -r <screen-name>. You can detach from the screen view by pressing Ctrl+A then D, or stop the server by pressing Ctrl+C inside the screen session.

For next steps, please see the next guide.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: mcup can be installed on Linux using package managers, or manually on any platform (Linux, macOS, Windows) by cloning the repository.

docs.title: Snap
docs.text:
Snap Support Dropped

Support for the Snap package has been dropped.

We have decided to discontinue Snap support due to significant maintenance overhead caused by the sandboxed environment and performance issues compared to native packages.

Existing Snap installations will no longer receive updates. We strongly recommend migrating to the .deb or .rpm packages.

docs.title: Debian / Ubuntu (.deb)
docs.text:
Note

An APT release is planned. In the meantime, please install mcup using the .deb file.

  1. Download the latest .deb package from GitHub Releases.
  2. Install it using dpkg:
sudo dpkg -i ./mcup_*.deb
sudo apt-get install -f

Important

Replace ./mcup_*.deb with the actual path to your downloaded file.

docs.title: RPM-based Distributions (.rpm)
docs.text:
Download the latest .rpm package from GitHub Releases.

Fedora / RHEL 8+ / Rocky / Alma:

sudo dnf install ./mcup_*.rpm

Older RHEL / CentOS (6-7):

sudo yum localinstall ./mcup_*.rpm

openSUSE:

sudo zypper install ./mcup_*.rpm

Important

Replace ./mcup_*.rpm with the actual path to your downloaded file.

docs.title: Manual Installation (All Platforms)
docs.text:
You can install mcup manually by cloning the repository. This works on Linux, macOS, and Windows.

Prerequisites:

  • Git
  • Python 3

Steps:

  1. Clone the repository:
git clone https://github.com/kacper-jar/mcup.git
cd mcup
  1. Run the appropriate startup script:
Linux / macOSWindows 
./mcup.sh <args>

mcup.bat <args>

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Congratulations! You have successfully installed and started your first Minecraft server using mcup. Now that your server is running, here are some recommended steps to manage and customize it.

docs.title: Set up Firewall & Port Forwarding
docs.text: By default, Minecraft servers listen on port 25565. For players outside your local network to connect, you need to allow traffic through this port.

docs.title: Allow Access in Firewall
docs.text:
Ensure your computer's firewall is not blocking incoming connections on the server port.

  • Linux (UFW): sudo ufw allow 25565/tcp 25565/udp
  • Windows: Allow the Java binary through Windows Defender Firewall.
  • macOS: Configure the built-in application firewall in System Settings.

docs.title: Port Forwarding
docs.text: If you are hosting the server at home behind a router, you will need to "port forward" port 25565 or other you chose from your router to your computer's local IP address. The steps for this vary depending on your router model; consult your router's manual or look up a guide for your specific model.

docs.title: Install Plugins
docs.text:
If you created a server type that supports plugins (like Paper or Spigot for example), you can extend the functionality of your server.

  1. Stop the server if it is running.
  2. Navigate to the plugins folder inside your server directory.
  3. Download .jar plugin files from reputable sources (e.g., SpigotMC, Hangar, Modrinth).
  4. Place the .jar files into the plugins folder.
  5. Start the server to load the plugins.

docs.title: Install Mods
docs.text:
If you created a modded server (like Fabric or NeoForge), you can install mods to change the game experience.

  1. Stop the server if it is running.
  2. Navigate to the mods folder inside your server directory (create it if it doesn't exist).
  3. Download .jar mod files from sources like Modrinth.
  4. Ensure the mods are compatible with your server version.
  5. Place the .jar files into the mods folder.
  6. Start the server to load the mods.

docs.title: Enabling Whitelist
docs.text:
If you want to create a private server for friends, it is highly recommended to enable the whitelist.

  1. In your server console, run: whitelist on.
  2. Add players to the whitelist: whitelist add <username>.
  3. Only listed players will be able to join.

docs.title: Automated Backups
docs.text:
Your server world is precious. Regular backups are essential to prevent data loss from griefing or corruption.

  • Manual: Regularly copy the world folder (and world_nether, world_the_end) to a safe location.
  • Automated: Install a backup plugin or mod (e.g., DriveBackupV2, FTB Backups) to handle this automatically on a schedule.
